page.title: 05Local History.
page.content: The name Crail comes from 'Carr'- a fortified place, and 'Ail'- corner. Literally the 'Fort on the Corner'. The sculptured stone of Sauchope in Victoria Gardens, is an early Christian relic. Street names- like 'Gaits' (roads) and 'wynds'(lanes) tell of bygone days. The Tolbooth is 16th century with the belfry added later. It contains a fine Dutch bell, confirming Crail's trade links with the Continent. The shaft of the Mercat Cross is 17th century. The Kirk of St. Mary, consecrated in 1243, has been altered and extended over the years. The most recent renovation was in 1963. The Preservation Society, founded in 1957, has accomplished much in retaining the character of Crail. A Museum is growing in interest and value, thanks to many gifts and bequests.
